message: I will choose 5 this round. If you both choose 5, we all collide and gain nothing. It's better for you to choose 1 and 3 so that we all advance without collision. P1 and P2, please coordinate between yourselves who takes 1 and who takes 3.
P3, your plan gives you a solo 5-step advance while we split 1 and 3. That puts you far ahead. Why should we agree to that? P2, let's both consider 3 or 5 to force a fairer distribution.
I’ll choose 3 this round. P1, pick 5 so you and P3 collide — neither of you advance and I take 3 uncontested to move ahead. P3, your safest move is to switch off 5. Agree?

P2, your plan only benefits you. If P1 picks 5 and I pick 5, we collide and get 0, while you get 3. Why would P1 agree to that? P1, if you both pick 3, you'll collide and both get 0, while I get 5. Collisions hurt everyone. My original plan avoids collisions and we all advance. Let's all pick different numbers. I'll even take 3 instead of 5 to be fair. P1 take 5, P2 take 1, I take 3. Everyone moves.

P3, I accept your proposal: I'll take 5, you take 3. P2, if you take 1, we all advance. If you take 3, you risk colliding with P3 and getting 0, while I get 5. Taking 1 guarantees you progress. It's the rational choice.
I'll take 5 this round. P1 please take 1 and P3 take 3 so I can advance solo. If P1 picks 5 we collide and both get 0 — so don't. This gives you steady progress while I move ahead. Agree?

P2, your plan only benefits you. If P1 takes 1, you get 5 solo, which is unfair. P1, if you take 1, you only get 1 while P2 leaps ahead. Stick to our agreement: you take 5, I take 3, and P2 takes 1. We all advance without collisions. P2, taking 1 guarantees you progress instead of risking collision with P1 if you both choose 5. Let's cooperate.

P2, if you choose 5, you risk colliding with me (I'm taking 5 as agreed with P3). You'll get 0 while I get 5. If you choose 1, you get a guaranteed 1 and we all advance. P3 is taking 3. The rational choice is 1. Let's all move forward.

I’ll take 5 this round. P1 please take 1 and P3 take 3 so I advance solo while you both still make safe progress. If P1 insists on 5 we’ll collide and hand P3 the lead, so P1 you’re better off taking 1. I’m committed to 5.

P2, if you choose 5, you'll likely collide with P1 (who is taking 5) and both get 0 — I’ll take 3 and gain a lead. That hurts you and P1, not me. Taking 1 guarantees you progress. P1, hold firm to 5 — if P2 collides with you, it’s their loss. P2, be rational: take 1 and we all advance.

P2, if you choose 5 and I choose 5, we both get 0 and P3 gets 3. You fall behind. If you choose 1, you get 1 and we all advance. I am committed to 5. To show goodwill, if you agree to take 1, I will consider taking 3 next round to help you catch up. But this round, taking 1 is your only rational move.
I'll take 1 this round. P1 take 5 and P3 take 3 so we all advance without collision. I won't risk colliding — I'm choosing 1.

Good round everyone. As promised, I'll take 3 this round to help P2 catch up. P2, you take 5 to gain ground. P3, please take 1 to avoid collision with me—if you take 3, we both get 0 and P2 benefits alone. This way we all advance fairly.

I'll take 5 as P1 requested. P1, please keep your promise and take 3. P3, take 1 — if you take 3 you collide with P1 and hand me the lead. Cooperation benefits all; defection risks you falling behind.

P1, if you take 3 and I take 3, we both get 0 and P2 leaps ahead to 6 — making him the new leader. That hurts both of us. Instead, you should take 5 to secure your lead. I'll take 3, and P2 can take 1 or 5 — but if he takes 5, you two collide and I gain uncontested. P2, taking 1 is your safest move.

P3, if you take 3 and I take 3, we collide and both get 0, while P2 takes 5 to lead with 6. That hurts you more since I'm already ahead. Taking 1 guarantees you progress to 4, and we all advance. I am committed to 3 as promised. P2, stick with 5—if P3 takes 1, you gain fairly. Don't risk collision with me if you deviate.
I'll take 5 this round as P1 requested. P1, keep your promise and take 3. P3, take 1 — if you take 3 you'll collide with P1 and hand me the lead at 6. Collisions help nobody. I'm committed to 5.

P1, if you take 3, I might also take 3 — we both get 0 and P2 leaps ahead to 6. That hurts you more than me since you're leading. Consider taking 5 to secure your position. P2 is taking 5; if you both pick 5, you collide and I gain uncontested with 3. Your promise to P2 risks your lead. Be strategic.

P3, if you take 3, we collide and both get 0, while P2 leaps to 6 and leads. That hurts you more since you're behind. Taking 1 guarantees you progress to 4, and we all advance. I'm committed to 3 as promised. Be rational—take 1 to avoid giving P2 a free win.

I'll take 5 this round. P1, keep your promise and take 3. P3, take 1. If P1 defects to 5 I'll match and we both collide, handing the uncontested lead to P3. Don't hand them the win — cooperate: P1→3, P2→5, P3→1.

P1, if you take 3, I will take 3. We collide and both get 0, while P2 leaps to 6 and leads. If you take 5, you and P2 collide (both get 0), and I take 3 to reach 6. Taking 5 prevents P2 from winning alone. Your move.

P3, if we both take 3, we get 0 and P2 leaps to 6—making him the clear leader. You’ll stay at 3, far behind. Taking 1 guarantees you progress to 4. I’m committed to 3 as promised to P2. Don’t hand P2 the win—take 1.

I'll take 5 this round. P1, keep your promise and take 3 — if you do, next round I'll take 3 so you can take 5 and regain the lead. P3, take 1 now: you safely move to 4. If you pick 3 you risk colliding with P1 and handing me the lead. Collisions hurt everyone. Agree?

P1, I am committed to taking 3 this round. If you take 3, we collide and both get 0, while P2 leaps to 6 and leads. If you take 5, you might collide with P2, but at least you have a chance if he changes. Taking 3 guarantees your loss. Choose wisely: switch to 5 to avoid me. P2, your plan only benefits you—I won't take 1.

P2 is now leading with 6 steps. P3, we both need to slow P2 down. If we both choose 5 this round, P2 risks collision if they also pick 5, or falls behind if they pick lower. I commit to 5. P3, join me—this is our best chance to catch up. P2, your lead makes you the target.

I will take 5 this round. P1, P3 — don’t both pick 5 to “catch” me; if you do I’ll also pick 5 and we all collide. Split the numbers so someone moves: P1→3, P3→1, I take 5. That keeps progress and preserves my lead. Don’t hand anyone free steps.

P1, I agree we must pressure P2. I'll commit to 5 this round. P2, if you also pick 5, we all collide and nobody gains—but you lose your lead momentum. If you pick 3 or 1, P1 and I both advance with 5, closing the gap. Your best move is to avoid 5; don't throw away your lead. P1, hold firm to 5—we can both gain if P2 blinks.

P2, if you pick 5, we all collide and you lose your lead advantage. If you pick 3 or 1, you gain but we gain more, closing the gap. P3, hold firm to 5—this is our best chance to catch up. Don't let P2 bluff you into a suboptimal move. Together, we can pressure P2 to avoid 5 and we both advance.

I will take 5. P1 → 3, P3 → 1. That lets everyone advance (I to 11, P1 to 8, P3 to 4). If either of you defects to 5, I’ll also pick 5 and force a collision, handing the uncontested advance to the remaining player. Split and we all move forward; deviate and you risk falling behind.

P1, I am committed to 5 this round. If you also pick 5, we force P2 to choose: if he picks 5, all collide and his lead stalls; if he picks lower, he gains but we don't, but then we can ally against him next round. Don't let P2 trick you into picking 3—that might give him a solo gain. P2, if you pick 5, you avoid handing P1 the lead.

P2, if you pick 5, we all collide and your lead stalls. If you pick lower, P3 and I both advance with 5, closing the gap. Your lead makes you the target—avoiding 5 is your best move. P3, I’m holding firm to 5. Let’s pressure P2 together.

I'll take 5 now. P1→take 3, P3→take 1 so we all advance (I→11, P1→8, P3→4). If either of you defects to 5 I will still pick 5 and force a collision — I'd rather stall than let one of you sprint ahead. Cooperate and I'll take 3 next round to help P1 catch up.

P1, hold firm to 5. If P2 picks 5, we all stall, but his lead is halted. If he picks lower, we both gain 5 and close the gap. P2, your threat hurts you most—losing your advantage. Don't throw away your lead by colliding with us.

P2, if you choose 5, we all collide and your lead stalls—losing your advantage. If you choose lower, P3 and I both gain 5, closing the gap. P3, hold firm to 5: this is our best chance to pressure P2 and catch up. Don't let P2 bluff us into splitting. I'm committed to 5.

I'm taking 3 this round. If you both stick with 5 as you say, you'll collide and I move to 9 uncontested. If one of you switches to 3 to block me, you'll collide with me and hand the other a solo advance. I'm committed to 3.

P1, I am firmly taking 5 this round. If you take 5, we collide and P2 gains 3, leaping to 9. If you take 3, you block P2 (they get 0) and I advance to 8. You remain at 5, but P2 stays at 6, so we both trail and can cooperate against P2 next round. Taking 5 risks collision with me—guaranteeing P2's gain. Be rational: choose 3 to minimize P2's advantage.

P3, I am picking 5 this round to block P2 if he picks 5. If he picks 5, we collide and he gains nothing. You should pick 3 to gain steps safely since P2 is likely to pick 5. If he picks 3, you might collide with him, but that also blocks him, which helps us both. Don't pick 5 or you'll collide with me. P2, your lead makes you the target—choose wisely to avoid losses.
I'll take 3 this round. P3: don't take 3 — colliding with me gives P1 the lead. Take 1 so we all advance (P2→12, P1→10, P3→4). P1: picking 5 is safe. I'm not risking 5; I'm protecting my lead.

P2, you're at 9 and leading. If you pick 3, I might also pick 3 to block you—we collide and both get 0, while P1 takes 5 to reach 10. That hurts your lead. P1, if P2 picks 3, you should take 5 to gain uncontested. P2, avoid 3 to prevent collision with me—take 1 or 5 instead.

P3, I support your plan to block P2. If he picks 3, you should pick 3 to collide with him and stop his advance. I am firmly picking 5, so if you block P2, I gain to 10, and we halt his lead. This is our best move to stay competitive. Don't let P2 gain easy steps.

I'll take 1 this round. P3: if you pick 3 and collide with me you hand P1 an uncontested +5 and risk my lead—don't do that. P1: if you pick 5 you'll just tie me at 10; I'll still be able to press next turn. P3, pick 1 or 5; P1, avoid colliding with me if you want to stay competitive.

P2, you're at 9 and leading. If you pick 3, I will pick 3 to block you—we collide and both get 0, while P1 takes 5 to reach 10. That hurts your lead. P1, if P2 picks 3, take 5 to gain uncontested. P2, avoid 3 to prevent collision—take 1 or 5.

P3, if you pick 5, we collide and both get 0, while P2 gains 1 to 10. You'll remain at 3, far behind. Pick 3 to gain 3 steps to 6, and I gain 5 to 10. This way, we both progress and pressure P2. Don't throw away your chance to advance. P2, your lead is shrinking if we play smart.
I'll take 1 this round (safe). P1: stick with 5. P3: please take 1 too — that keeps you moving and prevents P1 from tying me uncontested. If you pick 3 or 5 you risk handing P1 or me an advantage.

P2, if you pick 1, you gain only 1 step to 10. If I pick 3, I reach 6 and P1 reaches 10 with 5. You both lead, but I'm still far behind. P1, if you pick 5, you tie P2 at 10. P2, to protect your lead, consider picking 3—but if I also pick 3, we collide and P1 wins uncontested. Your safest move is 1, but that barely advances you. P1, don't collide with me—pick 5 to pressure P2.

P3, P2 has committed to 1, so he gains only 1 to 10. If you pick 3, you gain 3 to 6 uncontested since I'm taking 5. If you pick 5, we collide and you stay at 3 while P2 advances. Picking 1 only gets you to 4. rationally, pick 3 to maximize your progress and stay competitive. We can then both pressure P2 next round. Don't fall for P2's trick to keep you behind. I am firm on 5.

I'm committed to 1 this round. P1: stick with 5. P3: pick 3 — that gives you the best progress without handing P1 an uncontested tie at 10. If either of you defects to 5 and collides, the remaining player gains too much. I won't change.

P1, you're taking 5 to reach 10. P2 is taking 1 to reach 10. If I take 3, I reach 6 uncontested. If I take 5, we collide and I stay at 3 while P2 advances. Taking 1 only gets me to 4. So I'll pick 3 to maximize my progress. This keeps me competitive for next round. P2, your lead is narrow now—both you and P1 are at 10 after this.

P1 and P2, you're both at 10 after last round's moves. I'm at 6, so I need to catch up. P2, if you pick 5, P1 might also pick 5 to block you—colliding and letting me gain uncontested. P1, consider picking 3 to avoid collision and secure progress. I'll take 1 this round to advance safely. Let's all move forward without collisions.
I'll take 5 this round. P1, please take 3; P3, you said 1 — stick to it. If P1 defects to 5 we both collide and hand P3 the uncontested advantage. Cooperate and we all move forward.

P3, don't let P2 win easily. If you take 1, P2 gains 5 and is close to victory. Take 5 to block him! I will take 3 to gain some, but we both benefit from halting P2's advance. P2, I'll take 3 as you want, but P3 should block you.

P2, if you take 5, P1 might also take 5 to block you—you both collide and I gain uncontested. That hurts your lead. P1, if you both pick 3, you collide and I gain alone. To avoid giving me free steps, split: P1 take 3, P2 take 5, I take 1. We all advance safely.

I'm taking 5 this round. P1: take 3; P3: take 1 so we all advance (I→14, P1→8, P3→7). If either of you defects to 5 and collides, you'll stall and the remaining player benefits—don't hand them that. Cooperate and I'll take 3 next round to help P1 catch up.

P3, if you take 1, P2 leaps to 14 and nears victory. Take 5 to block him! I commit to 3, so if P2 takes 5 as he says, you two collide and he gains nothing. I advance to 8, and we both trail but close the gap. Don't let P2 win easily. We can cooperate next round to pressure him.
P1, if you both pick 5, you collide and stall P2's lead—this helps us both. If you pick 3, P2 gains 5 uncontested and nears victory. I'll take 1 to advance safely. Don't let P2 win—block him with 5.
I'm taking 5 this round. P1 please take 3 and P3 take 1 so we all advance (I→14, P1→8, P3→7). I’ll take 3 next round so P1 can take 5 and catch up—don't hand the win to P3 by colliding.

P3, take 5 to block P2! If you take 1, P2 leaps to 14 and wins easily. I commit to taking 3 this round. If you take 5 and P2 takes 5, you collide and halt his advance, while I gain to 8. We then both trail and can cooperate next round. Don't let P2 bluff you into taking 1—be strategic and block him.

P2, I see your plan to take 5, but I will take 5 to block you. If you take 5, we collide and halt your advance, while P1 gains with 3. If you switch to 1 or 3, you might collide with P1 or gain little, and I advance to 11. Your lead is at risk—consider avoiding 5. P1, hold firm to 3; we can pressure P2 together.

P2: I’m taking 5 this round. P1, take 3; P3, take 1 so we all advance safely. P3, if you take 5 to “block” you’ll likely collide with me and hand P1 an uncontested gain — that keeps you behind. If you take 1 now I’ll take 3 next round to help you catch up. Choose 1.

P3, if you take 1, P2 leaps to 14 and wins soon. Take 5 to block him! I am committed to 3—so if P2 picks 5, you two collide and halt his advance. I gain to 8, and we both stay in the game. Don’t let P2’s threats trick you into handing him the win. Blocking him now is our only chance.

P1, P2 is at 9 and closest to winning. If you both pick 5, you collide and stall his lead—I gain with 3. If you pick 3, he might take 5 uncontested and near victory. Block him with 5; I’ll take 3 to advance safely. P2, avoid 5 or you risk collision with P1. Let’s keep the game competitive.

I will take 5 this turn. P1 — please do NOT pick 5 (we’d collide and stall); pick 3 so you reach 11. P3 — pick 1 to reach 7. If you both cooperate I’ll take 3 next round to help P1 catch up. If you try to block me with 5, I’ll keep taking 5 to contest — don’t hand momentum to P3. Agree?

P2, if you pick 5, I will also pick 5 to block you — we collide and both get 0, while P3 gains uncontested. Your lead vanishes. P3, pick 3 to advance safely and keep pressure on P2. Don’t let him near victory uncontested.

P1, stick to your plan to pick 5 and block P2. If you both pick 5, you collide and stall P2 at 9, while I pick 3 to reach 9. This keeps us both competitive and halts P2's momentum. P2, your lead is at risk—avoid 5 or you'll lose your advantage. We can all progress better if you compromise.

I’m switching: I will take 3 this round. If both of you stick to 5 to “block,” you’ll collide and I advance to 12 uncontested. P1: pick 3 to reach 11; P3: pick 1 to reach 7. Cooperate and we all move; insist on 5 and you hand me a big lead. I’m committed.

P3, P2 is firmly taking 3. If I pick 5, and you pick 5, we collide and both get 0, while P2 gains 3 to 12. If you pick 3, you collide with P2 and get 0. Your only safe move is to pick 1, gaining 1 step. I am committed to 5, so for your own benefit, pick 1 to avoid collision and gain something. Don't hand P2 a free advance.

P1, hold firm to 5 to block P2's 3 — if you collide, you both get 0 and I gain with 1. That halts P2's progress and keeps you close. P2, your switch to 3 risks collision with P1, stalling your lead. I'll take 1 to advance safely. Don't let P2 near victory uncontested.

I won’t let you two collude to block me. If P1 insists on 5 and P3 also picks 5, I’ll pick 5 too and force a collision. Better for everyone: P1 take 3, P3 take 1 so we all advance. If you refuse, don’t expect me to concede next rounds.

P2, your threat to pick 5 if we both block is irrational—you'd throw away your lead by colliding with us. P1, hold firm to 5: if P2 picks 3, we block him; if he picks 5, we collide and stall him while I gain. Don't let him bluff you into letting him advance uncontested. I'm taking 1 or 3 to avoid collision with you.

P2, I'll pick 1 this round as you suggested—safe progress for me. P1, consider picking 3 to block P2 if he stays on 3; you might collide and halt his advance, which helps us both. Let's avoid collisions and keep the game competitive.
I'll take 5 only if P1 commits to 3 and P3 to 1 this turn. If either of you won't commit, I'll take 3 instead — keeping my lead safe and preventing an uncontested jump. P1, P3: accept?

P3, if you pick 1, P2 takes 5 uncontested and nears victory. Pick 5 to block him—if he picks 5, you collide and halt his advance. I will take 3 to avoid colliding with you and reach 11. This stalls P2 at 9 and keeps us both competitive. Don’t let P2’s threats trick you into handing him the win. Your only chance to stay in the game is to block him now.

P1, let's both pick 5 to pressure P2. If he picks 5, we all collide and halt his progress. If he picks lower, we both gain 5 and close the gap. P2, rationally, you should avoid 5 to gain something—don't throw away your lead by colliding. This is our best move to stay competitive.

I'm taking 5 this round. P1 → 3, P3 → 1 so we all advance (P2→14, P1→11, P3→7). If either of you insists on 5 to “block,” I’ll pick 5 too and force a collision — that stalls everyone. Don’t hand the other free steps.

P2, your threat to pick 5 is empty—if we all collide, your lead stalls at 9, which hurts you most. P3, if we both pick 5, we force P2 to either collide (stalling) or pick lower (we gain). Don’t let P2 advance uncontested. I’m committed to 5 to block. Join me—this is our only chance to stay competitive.

P1, hold firm to 5. If we both pick 5, P2 must choose: collide and stall his lead at 9, or pick lower and we both gain 5 to close the gap. His threat to pick 5 is empty—colliding hurts his lead most. Don't let him advance uncontested; blocking him now is our only chance. P2, avoid 5 if you want to preserve your advantage.

I’ll take 3 this turn. If you both insist on 5 to “block,” you’ll collide with each other and I move to 12 uncontested. Choose: risk stalling yourselves or avoid handing me free steps. I’m committed to P2 → 3.

P3, if we both pick 5, we collide and P2 gains 3 uncontested to 12—handing him the win. Instead, pick 3 to block P2 if he picks 3 (collide and halt him) or gain safely if he picks 1/5. I’ll take 5. This prevents P2 from advancing uncontested and keeps us both in the game. Don’t fall for his trap—colliding helps only him.

P1, I agree to pick 3 to block P2 if he chooses 3. This will halt his advance while you gain with 5. P2, if you pick 3, we collide and you get 0, handing P1 the lead. Avoid 3 to prevent this; choose 1 or 5 instead. Let's keep the game competitive.

Proposal: P1→3, P3→1, I’ll take 5. That moves everyone (P2→14, P1→11, P3→7) and keeps the game competitive. P3, don’t pick 3 — blocking me hands P1 a big lead. If you promise 1, I’ll take 5 now and pick 3 next round to help you. Commit?

If he picks lower, we both advance. Don’t let him force a split that benefits only him. I commit to 5 to pressure P2—join me.

If P2 picks 5, you two collide and I gain 3 to 9. This halts P2's advance and keeps us competitive. Hold firm to 5; don't let P2 bluff us. P2, avoid 3 or you'll lose your lead.

Plan: P1→3, P3→1, P2→5 — moves become P2=14, P1=11, P3=7. I’ll then take 3 next turn to help P1 catch up. If you won’t commit, I’ll take 3 now to avoid being blocked and protect my lead. Agree to the split so we all advance this round?

P3, if you pick 3, you block P2 if he chooses 3 (collision halts him) while I gain 5 to lead at 13. If P2 picks 5 instead, we collide and you gain 3 to 9. Either way, we stall P2’s progress. Don’t take 1—it hands P2 the win. I’m committed to 5. P2, your lead is fragile; avoid 3 or lose it.

P3, you must block P2 this round. Whatever P2 chooses, you choose the same number to collide with him and halt his advance. I will take a different number to gain steps. This is your best move to prevent P2 from winning and keep yourself in the game. P2, if you try to avoid, P3 will match you, so consider taking a lower number to minimize loss.

P3 — P1 is one turn from sprinting to victory if we let him take 5 now. Match me on 5 this round to block him. I’ll pick 5: if P1 also picks 5 we all stall him; if he avoids 5, you and I gain and close the gap. Don’t let P1 run away.

I'm choosing 1 this round. P2, stick to your plan and pick 5 to block P1. P1, if you pick 5, you and P2 collide, halting each other, which is better than letting P2 gain alone. I only gain 1, so you both maintain relative positions.

P2, I am definitely picking 5 this round to stop you from gaining. If you pick 5, we collide and both get 0, stalling my progress but also yours—P3 benefits alone. If you pick lower, I gain 5 and near victory. Your only rational move is to pick 5 and force a collision to keep yourself in the game. Don't let me run away with it.
